title: NT mine 'destroyed community livelihood'
text:
Fri, Aug 28, 2015, 12:08 PM AEST - Australia Markets close in 3 hrs 52 mins NT mine 'destroyed community livelihood' AAP – 10 minutes ago Print 
In allowing contaminants to leak into a Borroloola river, mining company Glencore has taken away the community's livelihood, a local says. 
Documents obtained by the Northern Territory's Environmental Defenders Office under freedom of information laws this week revealed that the NT government was aware last September of a litany of problems facing the MacArthur River lead and zinc mine near Borroloola, on the Top End gulf coast. 
A report from the Department of Mines and Energy (DME) to the Chief Minister said there were elevated levels of lead found in fish, invertebrates and cattle downstream from the mine, as well as in oysters and mussels in the Bing Bing Port shipping channel, and that the mine was experiencing serious problems with acid and metals leaching into waterways. 
The DME said the mine's actions regarding waste rock classification and management has not met current industry standards for many years, and that it was concerned the operator would not follow an appropriate closure plan to preserve the surrounding environment. 
The health department instructed Glencore to put up warning signs along two creeks and near the port warning people not to eat seafood caught there as it could pose a health risk, but that was only partially done. 
Gadrian Hoosan, a member of one of Borroloola's indigenous clans, said the community was worried about getting sick. 
"They had no right to contaminate our river; this river is our livelihood and we've been using it for many, many years, and they took that away from us," he told AAP on Friday. 
He said the community now believed the river is unusable. 
"We need them to clean the place; even if we do shut it down, they'll still leave the place destroyed, damaged," Mr Hoosan said. 
Earlier this week, Chief Minister Adam Giles said the mine would be shut down if it didn't comply with a government request to pay a larger environmental clean-up bond. 
He said the government would not accept a bond that does not support rehabilitation after closure, or environmentally risky practices at the site. 
But Glencore Chief Operating Officer Greg Ashe told a mining conference in Darwin this week that things had changed since the FOI data was collated. 
"Some of that information in fact is six or 12 months out of date and no longer reflects the current operating status of McArthur River," he said, and the next results would be much improved. 
Anna Boustead, acting director of the NT's Environment Centre, said: "All the evidence demonstrates that Glencore has been recalcitrant... it's been very slow to act and it's known about these issues for years." 
Glencore is now completing an environmental assessment study and continuing talks with the government about whether it will pay an increased environmental bond. @y7finance on Twitter, become a fan on Facebook Aust shares open higher AAP
